details.title: A New Three-Parameter Extension to the Birnbaum-Saunders Distribution
details.standardTitle: A New Three-Parameter Extension to the Birnbaum-Saunders Distribution

p: William J. Owen received his Ph.D. (1997) in Statistics from the University of South Carolina. From 1997 to 2002, he was Assistant Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of New Hampshire. Since 2002, he has served as an Assistant Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at the University of Richmond. He has published papers on reliability, life testing, parametric inference, and computer network security. He is an Associate Editor for the J. Statistical Computation and Simulation, and he is a member of the American Statistical Association.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Comput. Sci., Univ. of Richmond, VA
authors.name: W.J. Owen

details.abstract: The Binrbaum-Saunders (B-S) distribution was derived in 1969 as a lifetime model for a specimen subjected to cyclic patterns of stresses and strains, and the ultimate failure of the specimen is assumed to be due to the growth of a dominant crack in the material. The derivation of this model will be revisited, and because the assumption of independence of crack extensions from cycle to cycle can be quite unrealistic, one new model will be derived by relaxing this independence assumption. Here, the sequence of crack extensions is modeled as a long memory process, and characteristics of this development introduces a new third parameter. The model is investigated in detail, and interestingly the original B-S distribution is included as a special case. Inference procedures are also discussed, and an example dataset is used for model comparison

context.text: Aschar [1] derives the approximate Fisher information for (2), and considered Bayesian inferences using non-informative and Jeffrey's priors.

references.title:
Inferences for the Birnbaum-Saunders fatigue life model
using Bayesian methods
references.text: J. A. Ashcar, "Inferences for the Birnbaum-Saunders fatigue life model using Bayesian methods", Computational Statistics and Data Analysis, vol. 15, pp. 367-380, 1993.

context.text: A stochastic process \${\rm Y}_{1},{\rm Y}_{2},\ldots,{\rm Y}_{n}\$ is said to have “long memory” (or long range dependence) if the autocorrelation function  decays very slowly with increasing distance (either time or space) between observations (see Beran [2]).
Beran [2] examines certain processes where the variance of \$\overline{\rm Y}\$ differs not only by a constant multiplied by \$n^{-1}\$, but also by the speed at which it converges to zero.

Specifically, when a long memory process is self-similar (simply meaning that it is invariant in distribution under a scaling of time and space) with stationary increments, Beran [2] shows that  where \$\kappa\$ is the rate of decay, and is related to the self-similarity parameter for the process.

references.title: Statistics for Long-Memory Processes
references.text: J. Beran, Statistics for Long-Memory Processes, 1994, Chapman and Hall.

links.abstract: The assumption of a common underlying failure process leads to both the inverse Gaussian distribution and the fatigue life distribution of Birnbaum & Saunders. The first is obtained by an exact derivation while the second involves certain approximations. Although both of these distributions fit many failure data well, the inverse Gaussian distribution enjoys a distinct advantage in regard to the availability of procedures for a sound statistical analysis and tractability of the sampling distribu...

context.text: Of importance here are the works of Bhattacharyya & Fries [3], where the approach [4] is regarded as a Wiener process of accumulated fatigue in time.

references.title:
Fatigue failure models—Birnbaum-Saunders vs. inverse
Gaussian
references.text: G. K. Bhattacharyya, A. Fries, "Fatigue failure models—Birnbaum-Saunders vs. inverse Gaussian", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-31, pp. 439-441, Dec. 1982.

context.text: In 1969, Birnbaum & Saunders [4] derived a new family of lifetime distributions.
Because the precise derivation of the B-S model is an important aspect for this article, we will briefly summarize the steps given in Birnbaum & Saunders [4], and discuss their approach.
The distribution (2) has some interesting properties described in [4].
Of importance here are the works of Bhattacharyya & Fries [3], where the approach [4] is regarded as a Wiener process of accumulated fatigue in time.

references.title: A new family of life distributions
references.text: Z. W. Birbaum, S. C. Saunders, "A new family of life distributions", J. Applied Probability, vol. 6, pp. 319-327, Jun 1969.

context.text: For example, Birnbaum & Saunders [5] consider an example to model the strength of aluminum coupons subjected to cyclic stresses and strains.
The ML estimators for \$\alpha\$ and \$\beta\$, denoted by \$\hat{\alpha}\$ and \$\hat{\beta}\$, are derived in [5].
As an example with data modeling, we refer to the Birnbaum & Saunders [5] article where their model (2) is used to fit aluminum coupon failure data.
This particular sample is chosen because it appears to exhibit the poorest fit of the three as illustrated in the Cdf graphs given in [5].
For this dataset, Birnbaum & Saunders [5] give the ML estimates using (2) as \$\hat{\alpha}=0.3103\$, \$\hat{\beta}=1336.3784\$.

references.title:
Estimation for a family of life distributions
with applications to fatigue
references.text: Z. W. Birbaum, S. C. Saunders, "Estimation for a family of life distributions with applications to fatigue", J. Applied Probability, vol. 6, pp. 328-347, Jun 1969.

context.text: Coincidentally, Desmond [6] provides a more general derivation of the B-S model (2) based on stochastic processes; therein, he includes a model that yields a B-S-like distribution that can account for dependence in crack extensions.

references.title: Stochastic models of failure in random environments
references.text: A. F. Desmond, "Stochastic models of failure in random environments", Canadian J. Statistics, vol. 13, pp. 171-183, Sep. 1985.

links.abstract: The relationship between two fatigue life distributions, namely the Birnbaum-Saunders and the Inverse Gaussian, is further investigated. An intimate connection exists between the two models, viz, the Birnbaum-Saunders is a mixture of two probability distributions: 1) an Inverse Gaussian random variable, and 2) the reciprocal of an Inverse Gaussian random variable. Advantages and disadvantages of the two distributions are discussed. The arguments favour the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution from a s...

context.text: This result is later investigated in Desmond [7].

references.title:
On the relationship between
two fatigue-life models
references.text: A. F. Desmond, "On the relationship between two fatigue-life models", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-35, pp. 167-169, Jun. 1986.

links.abstract: The Birnbaum-Saunders distribution is prevalent in the engineering sciences as an effective means of modeling fatigue life. In practice however, there is no guarantee that the collected data follow such a model. Consequently, this paper considers the robust estimation of the parameters and quantiles of this distribution. Our robust estimation technique is based on OBRE (optimal bias-robust estimator) and assigns a weight to each observation and gives estimates of the parameters and quantiles bas...

context.text: Dupuis & Mills [8] consider an alternative to ML estimation for the B-S distribution that is shown to be robust to the presence of contaminated data.

references.title:
Robust estimation of the Birnbaum-Saunders
distribution
references.text: D. J. Dupuis, J. E. Mills, "Robust estimation of the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-47, pp. 88-95, 1998.

references.title:
Inferences on the parameters of the Birnbaum-Saunders fatigue
life distribution based on maximum likelihood estimation
references.text: M. Engelhardt, L. J. Bain, F. T. Wright, "Inferences on the parameters of the Birnbaum-Saunders fatigue life distribution based on maximum likelihood estimation", Technometrics, vol. 23, pp. 251-256, 1981.

context.text: Inference procedures for fitting (9) to complete samples \$t_{1},t_{2},\ldots t_{n}\$ can be accomplished using standard techniques; e.g., by ML or LS methods (see Lawless [10], or Meeker & Escobar [11] for a detailed overview of these procedures).
See Lawless [10] for a summary of the research on estimation with this distribution.

references.title: Statistical Models and Methods for Lifetime Data
references.text: J. F. Lawless, Statistical Models and Methods for Lifetime Data, 1982, John Wiley & Sons.

context.text: Meeker & Escobar [11] demonstrate that the hazard function for the standard B-S distribution (2) can either be strictly increasing; or increasing to a point in time, and then decreasing.

Inference procedures for fitting (9) to complete samples \$t_{1},t_{2},\ldots t_{n}\$ can be accomplished using standard techniques; e.g., by ML or LS methods (see Lawless [10], or Meeker & Escobar [11] for a detailed overview of these procedures).

references.title: Statistical Methods for Reliability Data
references.text: W. Q. Meeker, L. A. Escobar, Statistical Methods for Reliability Data, 1998, John Wiley & Sons.

context.text: The derivation of the B-S distribution can be viewed as consistent with a deterministic model from mechanics known as Miner's Rule [12].

references.title: Cumulative damage in fatigue
references.text: M.A. Miner, "Cumulative damage in fatigue", J. Applied Mechanics Trans. ASME, vol. 67, pp. A159-A164, 1945.

context.text: Desmond's research has, however, been instrumental in the development of “cumulative damage” models found in the literature (see, for example Owen & Padgett [13]).

references.title:
Acceleration models for system strength based on Birnbaum-Saunders
distributions
references.text: W. J. Owen, W. J. Padgett, "Acceleration models for system strength based on Birnbaum-Saunders distributions", Lifetime Data Analysis, vol. 5, pp. 133-147.

links.abstract: The 2-parameter family of probability distributions introduced by Birnbaum and Saunders characterizes the fatigue failure of materials subjected to cyclic stresses and strains. It is shown that the methods of accelerated life testing are applicable to the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution for analyzing accelerated lifetime data, and the (inverse) power law model is used due to its justification for describing accelerated fatigue failure in metals. This paper develops the (inverse) power law acceler...

context.text: Lastly, Owen & Padgett [14] derived a three parameter model based on the B-S distribution (2), but this was a consequence of substituting a covariate-dependent power law acceleration model for the \$\beta\$ parameter.

references.title:
A Birnbaum-Saunders accelerated
life model
references.text: W. J. Owen, W. J. Padgett, "A Birnbaum-Saunders accelerated life model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-49, pp. 224-229, Jun. 2000.

context.text: Other important efforts include a log-linear model for the B-S model derived in Rieck & Nedelman [15].

references.title: A log-linear model for the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution
references.text: J. R. Rieck, J. Nedleman, "A log-linear model for the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution", Technometrics, vol. 33, pp. 51-60, 1991.

context.text: The B-S distribution exhibits the reciprocal property [16]; that is, \${\rm S}^{-1}\sim{\rm B}-{\rm S}(\alpha,1/\beta)\$, so thus this reciprocal is in the same family of distributions (2) as the original random variable S.

references.title: A family of random variables closed under reciprocation
references.text: S. C. Saunders, "A family of random variables closed under reciprocation", J. American Statistical Association, vol. 69, pp. 539-553, 1974.

context.text: Interestingly, this is the identical feature of the generalized gamma distribution introduced by Stacy [17].

references.title: A generalization of the gamma distribution
references.text: E. W. Stacy, "A generalization of the gamma distribution", Ann. Mathematical Statistics, vol. 33, pp. 1187-1192.
